text: Transcriptional analysis of Epstein-Barr virus gene expression in EBV - positive gastric carcinoma : unique viral latency in the tumour cells .

Although case-oriented evidence for an association of Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) with gastric carcinoma has been accumulating recently , the interaction ( s ) between EBV and gastric epithelial cells is / are largely unknown .

In this study , we examined seven EBV - positive gastric carcinoma tissues for viral gene expression at the mRNA level , from which studies on the EBV oncogenicity in human epithelial cells will benefit .

Reverse transcription - PCR analysis showed that all seven EBV - positive tumour tissues constitutively expressed <extra_id_0> EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA) 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , but not <extra_id_0> EBNA2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA .

text: Transcripts from the BamHI-A region of the viral genome were detectable in all cases .

<extra_id_0> BZLF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and the product , an immediate-early gene for EBV replication , was not expressed in any of them , thereby suggesting that the tumour cells carried EBV genomes in a tightly latent form .

These findings further extended our previous data regarding EBV latency in gastric carcinoma cells at the protein level , and have affirmed that the programme of viral gene expression in the tumour more closely resembles 'latency I ' represented by Burkitt 's lymphoma than 'latency II ' represented by the majority of nasopharyngeal carcinomas .
